odeComponent.htmlView: Classicism and Romanticism are two musical periods that are closely connected. There is no sudden break between them, but rather a gradual transition. Some composers, especially Ludwig van Beethoven, act as a bridge between a style based on balance and order and another one focused on emotion and personal expression.

Classicism and Romanticism are two musical periods that are closely connected. There is no sudden break between them, but rather a gradual transition. Some composers, especially Ludwig van Beethoven, act as a bridge between a style based on balance and order and another one focused on emotion and personal expression.

Musical Classicism developed approximately between 1750 (death of J. S. Bach) and 1827 (death of Beethoven), during the period known as the Enlightenment. This era was marked by confidence in reason, progress and education. The bourgeoisie grew socially and economically and became the new audience for music.

This caused an important change: music stopped being exclusive to the Church and noble courts and began to spread through private salons and public concerts. In bourgeois (burguesía) homes, interest in learning to play instruments increased, which led to the growth of printed scores and music instruction books.

The composer gradually began to break free from traditional patronage (mecenazgo, protección de un doble). Although commissions and patronage still existed, some composers started writing more for the public and according to their own taste, for a specific noble.

odePagStructure.blockName: From ornamented Baroque to simple Clasicism

odeComponent.htmlView:
Classical music seeks balance, clarity and proportion. It moves away from the expressive excess of the Baroque period and focuses on elegant, ordered and easy-to-understand music.

Melodies are simple, regular and symmetrical, organised into clear phrases. Melody with accompaniment predominates, with a main melodic line clearly standing out over a simple harmonic accompaniment.

Musical forms are very well structured and clearly defined, especially the “sonata form”, which became the basis of much instrumental music.

odeComponent.htmlView:
Opera

Vocal music loses importance compared to instrumental music, but it continues to play an important role. Opera becomes one of the major genres of the period, with Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart standing out as one of its most important composers. The opera buffa is especially significant thanks to Mozart’s works. During this period, Italy stops being the only operatic reference in Europe. As a result, librettos are no longer written only in Italian, but also in vernacular languages. Therefore, the following types of opera emerge:

  • Singspiel: Singspiel: sung in German, which combines sung numbers with spoken dialogue  (Listening -> The Magic Flute by Mozart , The Queen of the Night’s aria)
  • French opéra-comique: which includes spoken dialogue and lighter musical content. (Listening -> Carmen by Georges Bizet, Aria - Habanera).

Opera seria in the Classical period was a genre that, although dominant, entered crisis due to its excessive virtuosity and its distance from dramatic action. This situation led to its reform by Christoph Willibald Gluck, who sought (buscar) to return opera to its dramatic essence. Gluck prioritised dramatic action and the text, deleting unnecessary ornaments and excessive vocal display. He also gave greater importance to the chorus and the orchestra, integrating them into the drama instead of using them as simple accompaniment. With this reform, Gluck aimed for clarity, balance and rationality, values closely linked to the ideals of the Enlightenment. (Listening -> Orfeo ed Eurídice by C.W. Gluck -> Orfeo’s Aria ) 

Religious vocal music

Religious music went into a certain decline, although Masses and Requiems were still composed. One outstanding example is the Requiem in re minor by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, one of the most important works of sacred music. Mozart’s Requiem is divided into several sections or musical numbers. Some of them are, in turn, divided into smaller parts. Some of these may sound familiar to you from what we studied about Gregorian Chant. We listen to these parts of the Requiem:

  • Introitus.
  • Dies Irae.
  • Confutatis Maledictis.

There is a myth about its composition. The myth of Mozart’s Requiem says that he died while composing it, sensing his own death. However, the reality is that it was a mysterious commission from a count who wanted to pass it off as his own work. Mozart died leaving the Requiem unfinished, and it was his student Franz Xaver Süssmayr who completed it based on Mozart’s sketches, creating the final version. This myth was reinforced by the film Amadeus (1984), where we see Salieri helping Mozart write the Requiem while Mozart is very ill.

odeComponent.htmlView:
Forms

Instrumental music is the main pillar of the Classical period. During this time, the musical forms that would structure Western music for centuries were developed and established. The most important ones are the sonata, the symphony, the concerto for soloist and orchestra, and chamber music, especially the string quartet.

  • The sonata is a composition for one or two instruments (often with piano), written in several movements.
  • The symphony is a large-scale work for full orchestra, also divided into several movements.
  • Chamber music is intimate music for small ensembles (quartets, trios, etc.), performed in small rooms and written for a few instruments.

Confusion about the sonata

When we talk about the sonata, there is often a lot of confusion. We must distinguish between sonata and sonata form.

  • The sonata is a complete musical work (a genre) for one or a few instruments, usually written in several movements.
  • Sonata form is the specific structure typically used in the first movement of these sonatas, but also in symphonies, string quartets and concertos. It is characterized by three main sections: exposition, development and recapitulation.

In other words:

  • Think of the sonata as a novel with several chapters (the complete work).
  • Sonata form is like the structure of one specific chapter inside that novel (Exposition, Development, Recapitulation).

Escuchamos:

  • Piano Sonata No. 16 in do major, first movement (sonata form), by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart.
  • Piano Sonata No. 14 in do-sharp minor, first movement (sonata form), by Ludwig van Beethoven.
  • Piano Sonata No. 14 in do-sharp minor, third movement (sonata form), by Ludwig van Beethoven.
  • Symphony No. 40 in sol minor, first movement (sonata form), by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart.
  • Symphony No. 5 in do minor, first movement (sonata form), by Ludwig van Beethoven.
  • Symphony No. 94, third movement (minuet form, a dance), by Joseph Haydn.

  • Piano Sonata No. 14 in do-sharp minor, first movement (sonata form), by Ludwig van Beethoven.
  • Piano Sonata No. 14 in do-sharp minor, third movement (sonata form), by Ludwig van Beethoven.
  • Symphony No. 40 in sol minor, first movement (sonata form), by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart.
  • Symphony No. 5 in do minor, first movement (sonata form), by Ludwig van Beethoven.
  • Symphony No. 94, third movement (minuet form, a dance), by Joseph Haydn.

odeComponent.htmlView:
The classical orchestra

During the Classical period, there was an important change in instruments. The harpsichord was replaced by the piano, which allowed greater control of sound intensity. The orchestra gradually became more stable and developed a fixed structure, with a predominance of strings and an increasingly important role for wind instruments. The Classical orchestra is smaller than the Romantic one and seeks balance between sections. The conductor used to play an instrument as he directed the orchestra.

Strings family

Bowed strings: they became the heart of the orchestra: violin, viola, cello and double bass (their numbers increased).



Percussive strings: the piano (pianoforte) was the main instrument, standing out for its dynamic versatility (ability to play loud and soft). It was fundamental in chamber music and concertos. In the Classical period, it had between 61 and 73 keys, depending on the model.



Woodwinds

They became fully integrated and expanded: flute, oboe, clarinet and bassoon.

Flute Oboe Clarinet Bassoon



Brass

Trumpet, horn and trombone (used more frequently).

Trumpet Horn Trombone



Percussion

timpani (very important), snare drum, cymbals, triangle and bass drum.


Timpani Snare Cymbals Triangle Drum

odeComponent.htmlView:
Women had a very limited role in public musical life. Many of them received musical training, but usually as a private activity, not as a profession. Some female composers managed to publish works or perform in aristocratic circles, but their recognition was limited and their presence on major stages was very small.

  • Maria Anna Mozart (1751-1829):  older sister of Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart. She was a talented harpsichordist and composer who wrote important works.
  • Anna Amalia de Prusia (1723-1787): princess and patron of the arts. She was a notable composer for harpsichord and violin and an important music collector.
  • Maddalena Laura Lombardini Sirmen (1744-1812): Viennese composer and pianist, protected by Haydn, known for her concertos and operas.
  • Marianne von Martínez (1744-1812): Viennese composer and pianist, protected by Haydn, known for her concertos and operas.
  • Maria Teresa Agnesi (1720-1793): from Milan, she was an outstanding harpsichordist and composer of operas and instrumental music.
  • Josepha Barbara Auernhammer (1758-1820): Viennese pianist and composer. She was an important musical figure in her time and was mentioned by Goethe.
  • Maria Antonia Walpurgis (1724-1780): Bavarian princess and composer who wrote operas and chamber music and played a key role at court.
  • Elisabetta de Gambarini (1730-1779):  from London, she was an organist, harpsichordist, singer, conductor and composer.

odeComponent.htmlView:
Musical Romanticism developed approximately between 1800 and 1890, in a Europe marked by the consequences of the French Revolution (1789), the first Industrial Revolution (second half of the 18th century), and the rise of nationalism. Society changed deeply, and the individual became the centre of cultural life.

The artist no longer seeks only to please others: they are seen as a creative genius—free, often misunderstood, and guided by feelings. Composers write works without commissions, following their creative impulse, which often leads to economic difficulties.

odeComponent.htmlView: Romantic music is based on the exaltation of emotions. In contrast to Classical regularity, composers now seek expressiveness, contrast, and intensity. Melodies are freer, harmony is enriched with chromaticism and changes of key, and music aims to deeply move the listener. Music speaks to the heart, not the reason, and becomes the art best able to express the inner world of the human being.

odePagStructure.blockName: The intimist Lied and the epic opera

odeComponent.htmlView:
During Romanticism, vocal music experienced great development.

The lied

The lied stands out especially: a short song for voice and piano based on a poem, in which text and music merge to express feelings. The main composer of lieder was Franz Schubert.

Listening:  Ellen’s Third Song “Ave Maria.” by Franz Schubert.

Opera

Romantic opera reached its peak. In Italy (G. Verdi), bel canto triumphed and later verismo (G. Puccini). In Germany, Richard Wagner stands out as the creator of musical drama and the use of the leitmotif.

  • Escuchamos: Libiamo ne'lieti calici (Brindis) from la Traviata by Verdi.
  • Escuchamos: Nessun dorma (aria) from Turandot by Puccini.
  • Escuchamos: Ride of the Valkyries (prelude) from Die Walküre by R. Wagner.

odePagStructure.blockName: The piano and the programatic music

odeComponent.htmlView:
Romantic instrumental music is more varied and expressive than Classical music.

Piano pieces

The piano (improved since the Classical period) became the leading instrument, both in virtuosic works and in short lyrical pieces. It gradually took the place of Classical chamber music.

  • Nocturnes: lyrical and calm melodies. Listening ->  Nocturne in mi flat major Op. 9 Nº2 by Chopin. 
  • Études: virtuosic pieces designed to overcome technical difficulties. Listening- >  Étude in mi major Op.10 Nº 3 "Tristesse" by by Chopin.
  • Preludes: short compositions, often free in form, expressing a moment or feeling. Listening ->  Prelude in mi minor Op. 28, No. 4 by Chopin.

Orchestras and ballets

The Romantic symphony, the concerto for soloist and orchestra, ballets, and programmatic music (symphonic poem) also developed. This music describes stories, landscapes, or extra-musical ideas. Sonata form is broken, modified, and expression becomes more important. Works are longer, more complex, and more emotionally intense than in the Classical period. Listening:

  • Symphony Nº 9 in mi minor. Fourth movement by Antonín Dvořák.
  • Piano Concerto No. 1 in si-flat minor, first movement (modified sonata form) by Piotr Ilich Tchaikovsky.
  • Swan Lake, Act IV Finale by Piotr Ilich Tchaikovsky.
  • The Moldau (symphonic poem) from Má vlast Nº2, by Bedřich Smetana.
  • 1812 Overture by Piotr Ilich Tchaikovsky.

odeComponent.htmlView:
The Romantic orchestra grew enormously in size and timbral variety. Wind instruments were improved and the percussion section expanded. The piano reached 88 keys and has kept this number to the present day.

A fundamental figure appeared: the conductor, who became essential to coordinate large instrumental forces and to give a coherent and expressive interpretation of the work. The conductor became an artist, with a personal musical vision. The conductor often played an instrument while leading the orchestra with a baton (batuta).

odeComponent.htmlView:
Although difficulties continued, Romanticism allowed greater visibility for some women in music, especially as performers. A notable example is Clara Schumann, a great pianist and composer. Even so, many women saw their careers limited by the social norms of the time, and their recognition as composers was far less than that of men. Notable figures include:

  • Clara Schumann (Germany, 1819-1896).
  • Fanny Mendelssohn (Germany, 1805-1847).
  • Cécile Chaminade (France, 1857-1944).
  • Amy Beach (United States, 1867-1944).
